misconceptions.name: Reads multiple point coordinates instead of a single numeric grade
misconceptions.description: The program is set up to read four double values (x1, y1, x2, y2) for a distance calculation instead of reading a single numeric grade between 0 and 100 as required by the problem. This means the criterion for correctly reading the numeric grade input is not met (0/1 points).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to read coordinates for two points (x1, y1, x2, y2) from the keyboard in order to compute a distance.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read exactly one numeric grade (0–100) from the user, e.g., using a single Scanner call such as nextInt() or nextDouble() into a variable like grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1 and y1, then x2 and y2 instead of a grade.
No variable representing a numeric grade is present.
Input type is double coordinates rather than a single grade value.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion about the problem requirements, likely using code from a different assignment (distance between points) instead of implementing the grade calculator.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the coordinate-reading methods with a single input step that asks for and stores a numeric grade between 0 and 100, e.g., `System.out.print("Enter grade: "); int grade = input.nextInt();`.
related_concepts: Using Scanner to read numeric input
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input operations and prompts clearly target point coordinates rather than a single grade; there is no reference to grades anywhere in the code.

evidence.note: Main method reads four coordinate values and never reads a single grade value between 0 and 100.
Prompt and input explicitly refer to coordinates x1 and y1, not a grade.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for A and B
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional checks for A and B grade ranges
misconceptions.description: There are no if/else or other conditional statements that check whether the numeric grade is within 90–100 (A) or 80–89 (B). As a result, the Boolean ranges for A and B are not implemented at all (0/1 points).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that computing a geometric distance is the task, so they do not include any grade range checks.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use conditional statements to test whether the input grade falls within 90–100 for A and 80–89 for B, e.g., `if (grade >= 90) ... else if (grade >= 80) ...`.
symptoms: No if/else or switch statements in the program.
No Boolean expressions comparing a grade variable to 90 or 80.
Computation focuses solely on arithmetic for distance.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student reused or wrote code for a different problem and never implemented any conditional grade logic.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if/else-if chain that checks the grade starting from the highest range (A: 90–100, then B: 80–89) and branches appropriately.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire class contains no conditional statements, and there is no grade variable to test; thus A/B ranges cannot be implemented.

evidence.note: Main method has no grade variable and no conditional logic; the entire program lacks if/else statements needed to implement A and B ranges.

misconceptions.task: Correct Boolean ranges for C and D
misconceptions.name: Missing conditional checks for C and D grade ranges
misconceptions.description: The program does not include any Boolean checks for 70–79 (C) or 60–69 (D); in fact, no grade-based Boolean logic is present at all. Thus the C and D ranges are entirely unimplemented (0/1 points).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student focuses on computing the distance between two points and does not consider middle grade ranges.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After checking A and B, the program should continue with conditions for C (70–79) and D (60–69), e.g., `else if (grade >= 70)` and `else if (grade >= 60)`.
symptoms: No conditions involving boundaries 70 or 60.
No mid-range branching logic.
Single linear computational path without decisions.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to implement any of the grade range logic specified in the problem, likely due to working on an unrelated distance problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Extend the if/else-if chain after the B case to include checks for C and D ranges in descending order of grade.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no conditionals anywhere; therefore C and D range logic is completely absent.

evidence.note: Method performs only arithmetic for distance; there is no conditional logic for any grade range, including C and D.

misconceptions.name: No default or else case to represent F grades
misconceptions.description: Because there is no conditional structure at all, there is no default or else branch to handle grades below 60 as F. The required catch-all behavior for F is missing (0/1 points).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student did not consider any grade categories, including the failing case, due to focusing on a different computational problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: After testing for A, B, C, and D, the program should use an else branch (or an explicit condition) to classify any remaining grades (below 60) as F.
symptoms: No else branch or equivalent default handling.
Program output never mentions F or any grade classification.
Single fixed message printed regardless of input.
misconceptions.root_cause: The absence of any grade classification logic means there is no way to represent the F case.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a final `else` in the conditional chain that prints letter grade F for all grades that did not match A–D ranges.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No if/else structure is present; therefore no default F case can exist.

evidence.snippet: System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: The only output is a distance message; there is no conditional or default branch that could produce an F grade.

misconceptions.task: Mapping each range to correct letter output
misconceptions.name: Outputs distance message instead of letter grade for each range
misconceptions.description: The program never prints a letter grade (A, B, C, D, or F). It always prints a distance-related message, so the mapping from numeric ranges to letter grade output is not implemented at all (0/1 points). Overall score for this submission on the rubric is 0/5.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required output is the numeric distance between two points, not a letter grade corresponding to an input grade.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should print `Letter grade: X` where X is one of A, B, C, D, or F depending on the numeric grade's range, matching the sample run format.
symptoms: Output string references "distance of the two points" instead of "Letter grade".
No occurrences of characters 'A', 'B', 'C', 'D', or 'F' as grade outputs.
Output does not depend on grade ranges.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misinterpretation of the assignment led to implementing distance calculation output rather than letter grade output.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the distance print statement with one that prints the correct letter grade for the given numeric grade, e.g., `System.out.println("Letter grade: " + letter);`.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical labels
Following problem specifications and sample runs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only printed message is about distance; there is no code that could ever output a letter grade.

evidence.snippet:
double distance = computeDistance(x1, y1, x2, y2);

System.out.println("The distance of the two points is " + distance);
evidence.note: Final output reports a numeric distance instead of a letter grade, contradicting the required sample run and mapping of ranges to letters.

misconceptions.name: Implemented an unrelated distance calculator instead of grade calculator
misconceptions.description: The student wrote a full program to compute the distance between two points rather than a program that reads a single numeric grade and outputs the corresponding letter grade. As a result, none of the rubric requirements for reading a grade, checking grade ranges, or printing a letter grade are addressed.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving a distance-between-points problem is acceptable for this question, instead of implementing the specified grade-to-letter mapping.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this question, the program should read one numeric grade (0–100) from the user and then use conditionals to map that numeric grade to a letter grade (A, B, C, D, F) according to the given ranges, finally printing the letter grade.
symptoms: Program prompts for x1, y1, x2, y2 instead of a single numeric grade.
Program computes a Euclidean distance using Math.sqrt rather than checking grade ranges.
Program prints a distance value, not a letter grade like A, B, C, D, or F.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion about the problem requirements or reuse of code from a different assignment without adapting it to the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Discard or repurpose this distance-calculation logic and instead: (1) read a single numeric grade (int or double) from the user, (2) use an if/else-if/else chain to test the grade against the specified ranges (90–100, 80–89, etc.), and (3) print the corresponding letter grade exactly as required.
related_concepts: Mapping numeric ranges to categorical outputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program is focused on distance calculation between points; there is no code related to reading a grade or printing a letter grade, so the mismatch with the assignment is unambiguous.

evidence.note: Main method reads four coordinate values and computes distance; it does not read a numeric grade or print a letter grade.
Input methods prompt for coordinates (x1, y1) rather than a single grade value.
Core computation is Euclidean distance, not any grade range checking or mapping to letter grades.
